audio, and then start a speech recognition task to live transcribe the meeting while it is
Let’s start with the simpler and more manageable task of simply asking the user for permission
to transcribe their audio. Even this brings up some interesting design considerations.

abstract.text: The first major piece of logic and behavior we will introduce to the record meeting feature is
the timer. This is a long-living effect that runs in parallel with the rest of the feature, and
we need to implement nuanced logic to figure out when to proceed to the next speaker.

doc://ComposableArchitecture/tutorials/C.title: Adding a new sync-up to the list

abstract.text: We now have two features built: the sync-ups list and the sync-up form. These features do not
exist in isolation, but rather are meant to be integrated in a deep way. One should be able to
navigate to the sync-up form from the list view, enter the details of a new sync-up, and then
add that sync-up to the root list.
Creates a persistence key that can read and write to a
value to the file system.
Now that we have a navigation stack in place we can start navigating to other features in the
application. The simplest is the meeting screen, which allows you to see the details of a
previous recorded meeting.
The first major piece of logic and behavior we will introduce to the record meeting feature is
the timer. This is a long-living effect that runs in parallel with the rest of the feature, and
we need to implement nuanced logic to figure out when to proceed to the next speaker.
Now that we have a navigation stack in place we can start navigating to other features in the
application. The simplest is the meeting screen, which allows you to see the details of a
previous recorded meeting.
Let’s implement two major pieces of functionality in the detail screen: editing the sync-up and
deleting the sync-up. This will force us to face a number of common problems in app development
all at once, including view reuse, navigation, alerts, and parent-child communication patterns.
Let’s implement two major pieces of functionality in the detail screen: editing the sync-up and
deleting the sync-up. This will force us to face a number of common problems in app development
all at once, including view reuse, navigation, alerts, and parent-child communication patterns.
Now that we have a navigation stack in place we can start navigating to other features in the
application. The simplest is the meeting screen, which allows you to see the details of a
previous recorded meeting.
Let’s start with a tour of the application we will be building. It’s called SyncUps, and it’s a
recreation of Apple’s Scrumdinger demo application.
We will begin building the SyncUps app from scratch by implementing the feature that powers the
list of sync-ups. It starts out as a simple feature, but it will become increasingly complex as
the app evolves.
We have now integrated two moderately complex features, the
and
, and
so its time to write some tests. This will give us the opportunity to prove that the features
work in tandem as we expect, and we will explore “non-exhaustive” testing to make our tests less
fragile.
The first major piece of logic and behavior we will introduce to the record meeting feature is
the timer. This is a long-living effect that runs in parallel with the rest of the feature, and
we need to implement nuanced logic to figure out when to proceed to the next speaker.
We will create a new feature with the Composable Architecture that is capable of editing the
details of a new sync-up. We will also add some nuanced logic around how focus moves through the
feature to make things a little more interesting.
We now have a moderately complex feature for editing the details of a sync-up, the
reducer. Let’s get some test coverage on the feature, and doing so will force us to come
face-to-face with dependencies for the first time in this tutorial.
We will create a new feature with the Composable Architecture that is capable of editing the
details of a new sync-up. We will also add some nuanced logic around how focus moves through the
feature to make things a little more interesting.
We will begin building the SyncUps app from scratch by implementing the feature that powers the
list of sync-ups. It starts out as a simple feature, but it will become increasingly complex as
the app evolves.
The SyncUpsList feature we have built so far isn’t very complex. In fact, it only has one
primary action, that of deleting sync-ups from its collection. However, it can be good practice
to test new features as you add them, and in the future we will have much more complicated
behavior to test.
We will begin building the SyncUps app from scratch by implementing the feature that powers the
list of sync-ups. It starts out as a simple feature, but it will become increasingly complex as
the app evolves.
We now have two features built: the sync-ups list and the sync-up form. These features do not
exist in isolation, but rather are meant to be integrated in a deep way. One should be able to
navigate to the sync-up form from the list view, enter the details of a new sync-up, and then
add that sync-up to the root list.
We now have a moderately complex feature for editing the details of a sync-up, the
reducer. Let’s get some test coverage on the feature, and doing so will force us to come
face-to-face with dependencies for the first time in this tutorial.
The “sync-up detail” screen shows all the information of a sync-up, and has many actions that
can take place in the screen. The user can edit the sync-up, or start a new meeting in the sync
up, or drill-down to a past meeting, or even delete the meeting.
The SyncUps application is a recreation of one of Apple’s more interesting demo applications,
Scrumdinger. We recreate it from scratch using the Composable Architecture, with a focus on
domain modeling, controlling dependencies, and testability.
We will wrap the application built so far in a
so that we can navigate to
the detail screen. To do this we will create a new root-level feature that will be responsible
for implementing the logic of the stack and integrating all of the features together.
Let’s implement two major pieces of functionality in the detail screen: editing the sync-up and
deleting the sync-up. This will force us to face a number of common problems in app development
all at once, including view reuse, navigation, alerts, and parent-child communication patterns.
We now have two features built: the sync-ups list and the sync-up form. These features do not
exist in isolation, but rather are meant to be integrated in a deep way. One should be able to
navigate to the sync-up form from the list view, enter the details of a new sync-up, and then
add that sync-up to the root list.
The SyncUpsList feature we have built so far isn’t very complex. In fact, it only has one
primary action, that of deleting sync-ups from its collection. However, it can be good practice
to test new features as you add them, and in the future we will have much more complicated
behavior to test.
The
feature has slowly become quite complex. It now handles two forms of
navigation (an alert and sheet), it models navigation state with a single enum, and it
communicates with a parent feature via delegate actions. It’s about time we got some test
coverage on this feature so we can be sure it works as we expect, and so that we can make future
changes with confidence.

so that we can navigate to

for implementing the logic of the stack and integrating all of the features together.

The first major piece of logic and behavior we will introduce to the record meeting feature is
the timer. This is a long-living effect that runs in parallel with the rest of the feature, and
we need to implement nuanced logic to figure out when to proceed to the next speaker.
Let’s get the basics of a new feature into place that we can navigate to, and then we will
slowly layer on its complex logic and behavior, such as the timer and speech recognizer.

recreation of Apple’s Scrumdinger demo application.

A property wrapper type that shares a value with multiple parts of an application.
We have now implemented a navigation stack at the root of our application, and integrated
3 features into the stack: the
feature, the
feature, and the
. Some of these features have quite complex logic binding them together, such as
when one deletes a sync-up from the detail screen it should pop the screen off the stack.
Now that we have the ability to add and remove sync-ups from the application, let’s add some
persistence. This will involve using the “shared state” tools from the library, such as

We have just one feature left to implement, and it’s one of the most complicated ones. We need
to use Apple’s
API to ask the user for permission to transcribe their
audio, and then start a speech recognition task to live transcribe the meeting while it is
in progress.

slowly layer on its complex logic and behavior, such as the timer and speech recognizer.

persistence. This will involve using the “shared state” tools from the library, such as

We have just one feature left to implement, and it’s one of the most complicated ones. We need
to use Apple’s
API to ask the user for permission to transcribe their
audio, and then start a speech recognition task to live transcribe the meeting while it is
in progress.
